videoInfo.title: How We Catch a Year’s Worth of Food in a Single Day: Munkha Ice Fishing in Yakutia
videoInfo.summary: The video documents Munkha, a traditional ice fishing method in Yakutia, Siberia, crucial for families to gather food for the long winter. It highlights the community effort, ancient rituals, and ingenious techniques passed down through generations, emphasizing its role as a cultural festival and a way of life. Despite challenges like climate change impacting ice thickness, the tradition endures as a testament to the Yakutian people's unity with nature and each other.

sections.title: Introduction to Munkha Ice Fishing in Yakutia

content.content: It's November now. Arian and his family are getting ready to go traditional ice fishing known as Munkha.
Munkha takes place every November, marking the final days before Yakutia's long and brutally cold winter begins.
It's only -15°C today, yet Arian and his family will spend the entire day outside.
They dress in layers, making sure to stay warm because once they reach the frozen lake, there is no coming back until the job is done.
Today is a big day for the whole village, as locals hope to catch several tons of crucial carp.
This catch is enough to feed families through the long winter months ahead.

sections.title: Ancient Traditions, Rituals, and Community Spirit

content.content: Before fishing begins, the leader and most experienced fisherman performs an ancient ritual, feeding the spirits of the forest, waters, and hunters.
In Yakutia, surviving the winter has always been a team effort; that's how this traditional form of ice fishing was born.
This ingenious ice fishing method has been passed down from father to son for thousands of years.
An elder of the village carefully chooses which lake will be fished this year, a decision made with deep respect for nature and the local ecosystem.
Over the years, Munkha has become more than just fishing; it's a true festival where people laugh, talk, and enjoy the last relatively warm day.
In Yakut culture, respect for elders runs deep; their words carry wisdom and tradition, teaching young boys about life, work, and strength.
Sacred rules dictate that those who have attended a funeral within 40 days or pregnant women are not allowed to join, as locals believe the lake can sense intense energy and will not give its gifts.
Teams of about 10 people gather, each with a specific role.
The strongest men cut two large holes in the thick ice where they will place a V-shaped net about 100 meters long.
Then they drill a series of smaller holes between them to guide the net underneath the ice using long wooden sticks with hooks.
Slowly, the net is pulled from one side of the lake to the other until it covers nearly the entire perimeter.
Arian's father, Kirill, prepares long wooden sticks for his son and wife, which they will use under the ice to drive the fish toward the net.
Fishing under the ice demands strength, patience, and perfect coordination.
Under the Munkha master's direction, the youngest fishermen stir the water through the holes, guiding the fish toward the center of the net.

sections.title: The Moment of the Catch and Distribution

content.content: When it's finally time to pull up the net, everything falls silent and time seems to stop.
Everyone holds their breath, wondering if there will be enough fish to feed their families through the long winter ahead.
Then the first silver fish appears, followed by hundreds more, and a cheer rises across the lake, signifying a great success this year.
When the catch is finally pulled out, the fish are equally shared among all participants and also with neighbors who could not take part.
Traditionally, Munkha begins in early November when the ice is already thick enough to hold thousands of people.
In recent years, because of rising temperatures in Siberia, the ice has become thinner and more fragile, making this tradition increasingly dangerous.
Yet the people continue because Munkha is not just fishing; it's their culture, their spirit, their way of life.
During the long Arctic winters, the ice grows so thick that oxygen can't reach the water, causing many fish to suffocate.
So, villagers catch them before that, gathering food while helping the lake stay in balance.
To protect nature, they never fish in the same lake for the next 3 years, allowing the ecosystem to restore its balance.

sections.title: Life in Yakutia: Unity, Love, and Joy

content.content: After a long day, tired but happy, Arian and his family are ready to return home.
Life in Yakutia is truly unique, harsh, but beautiful.
Through Munkha ice fishing, you can see how people here remain united with nature and with each other.
Even in the coldest inhabited place on Earth, life is filled with love, light, and joy.
